results.title: Tools for cutting: stone axes to lasers
results.brief_description: Cutting tools, like other devices and machines, reflect industrial development. The story of tools that cut, traces technological changes in a society beginning with stone axes and proceeding to devices that cut by the use of steel, diamonds water jet, electrochemical erosion, plasma jet and laser beam.

results.title: Tools and Equipment
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Safetycare”.
Selecting the correct tool for the task, inspecting the tool for damage before use, using the tool in the correct way and storing and carrying tools safely may all seem fairly obvious. These four basic rules for safe use of tools are straightforward but are often abused. This video looks at each of the basic rules and it also examines the safe use of ladders.

results.title: Tool steel manufacture
results.brief_description: Filmed at the works of Adcar Allen and Co Ltd, Sheffield. Shows the making of genuine double shear steel - the oldest Sheffield process. Includes pattern making (moulding by hand and machine); machining steel castings; tramway and railway trackwork.

results.title: Too old? Never
results.creator_credit: Summer Hill Films and Council on the Ageing (NSW)
results.brief_description: Sylvia feels invisible because a taxi driver treats her with condescension and takes the long route home despite her protests. She tells her friend Isobel, who encourages her to attend an information session about anti-discrimination legislation. There she meets Douglas, who has lodged a formal complaint to the Anti-Discrimination Board because he feels he is a victim of age discrimination in his workplace. Sylvia offers to be a support for Douglas when he must attend a mediation session with his team leader and the Board. Compromises are met and friendships are created in this informative short film. An ideal training tool for the workplace, classroom or discussion group.

results.title: Too much off the top
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The wonderful world of Paddington Bear”
During the slow season at Mr Gruber’s antique shop, Paddington decides to help his friend by repairing a cracked vase. While carrying the vase home he notices a “Help Wanted” sign in a barber shop window. He takes the job, thinking it will be a perfect way to make some extra money for Mr Gruber. Based on the book ‘Paddington at work’ by Michael Bond.

results.title: Too Much of a Good Thing
results.brief_description: A fascinating documentary that examines the connections between diet and health. Leading Australian nutritional scientists discuss the major “diseases of affluence” - cancers, cardiovascular disease and diabetes - that result from our everyday high fat, high salt, high sugar and low carbohydrate diet.
results.description: A fascinating documentary that examines the connections between diet and health. results.title: Too many Captain Cooks (A)
results.brief_description: This film seeks to replace the stereotypes promoted by the non-Aboriginal history of white settlement in Australia which usually begins with the ‘discoveries’ of Captain Cook. Here history is re-told from the point-of-view of the colonised: ‘Aboriginals discovered Captain Cook’. In Northern Australia white people are referred to as ‘Captain Cooks’. The film’s form is sensitive to the telling of tribal history of Captain Cook as spoken by Paddy Wambarranga of the Rembarrnga tribe in Arnhem Land. This history is also represented by images of Aboriginal art. Rembarrnga and Kriol dialogue with English subtitles.

results.title: Too little justice
results.creator_credit: Justin Davies, Marcus Waters, Dean Francis and AFTRS
results.brief_description:
“Everyday” racism escalates into violence as an indigenous school boy is forced to fight for dignity. When he is framed for drugs by a racist student, he realizes he is trapped in a cycle of systemic cultural bias.
Cast: George Barker, Shannon Cole
